mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is peculiar to the English, and, like most English peculiarities, the rest of the world finds it unintelligible.
`` The Nine Tailors `` was written by Dorothy L. Sayers
In the tower, ropes attached to the same five bells that first sounded here in 1614 are pulled rhythmically by five men and women.
But a discordant, modern note in Aslacton is also not heard by the church-goers, who are enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening.
Like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells, St. Michael's own `` band `` of ringers once heralded every Sunday morning and evening service.
Now, there remains only one local ringer: 64-year-old Derek Hammond.

A group of 15 ringers -- including two octogenarians and four youngsters in training -- is driven every Sunday from church to church in a sometimes-exhausting effort to keep the bells sounding in the many belfries of East Anglia by them.
The ranks of the East Anglian group that keeps the Aslacton bells pealing are feared to be diminished by Mr. Hammond due to old age and the flightiness of youth.
His side is not supported by history, after all.

A mind-boggling exercise called change-ringing, invented by the English 380 years ago, is required to demonstrate physical dexterity -- with some bells weighing more than a ton -- and intense mental concentration.
In `` rounds, `` proper English bells are started off from the highest-pitched to the lowest, creating a simple descending scale using, in larger churches, as many as 12 bells.
Then, at a signal, the order in which the bells sound is varied by the ringers without altering the steady rhythm of the striking.
The rules state that each variation, or change, can occur only once.
Patterns of changes are memorized by Ringers, known as `` methods, `` which have odd-sounding names such as Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A `` peal `` is comprised of a series of 5,000 or so changes and takes about three hours to complete.
An idea of the work involved is given by a look at a Thursday night practice at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington district of London.

A circle is formed by ten shirt-sleeved ringers, each with one foot ahead of the other in a prize-fighter's stance, pulling a rope that is disappearing through a small hole in the high ceiling of the ringing chamber.
No one is spoken to, and the snaking of the ropes seems to be made as much sound as the bells themselves, muffled by the ceiling.
Far above in the belfry, the huge bronze bells, which are mounted on wheels, are swung madly through a full 360 degrees, starting and ending, surprisingly, in the inverted, or mouth-up position.
The next swing is advanced or retarded by skilled ringers using their wrists, allowing one bell to swap places with another in the following change.

In a well-known detective-story involving church bells, the passion for ringing was described by English novelist Dorothy L. Sayers as one that finds its satisfaction in mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection.
`` Filled with the solemn intoxication that comes of intricate ritual faultlessly performed, `` she added, `` are Ringers.``
Stephanie Pattenden, master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's best female ringers, admits that ringing does become a bit of an obsession.
More often than not, the church is thought of by ringers as something stuck on the bottom of the belfry.
With membership of the Church of England steadily dwindling, equally strong-willed and often non-religious ringers are being pressed by strong-willed vicars to attend services.

Two years ago, the entire band was sacked by the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, because ringers who didn't attend service frustrated him; the ringers promptly set up a picket line in protest.
The tower was treated as sort of a separate premises by a self-perpetuating club, the Vicar Hummerstone says.
But more than six of the eight bells are still not rung by enough ringers.
At St. Mary's Church in Ilminster, Somerset, silence has fallen over the bells following a dust-up about church attendance.
It is refused to be talked about by the vicar, W.D. Jones, who says it would `` reopen the wound. ``
So crunch, crunch, crunch, bang, bang, bang -- the ringers from above are coming, making a very obvious exit as the congregation is at prayer, he says.
Mixed feelings are admitted by Vicar Marshall regarding this issue, since he is both a vicar and an active bell-ringer himself.
People are drawn into the church by the sound of bells, he says.
John C. Baldwin, president, says that relations with vicars are aimed to be improved by the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, a sort of parliament of ringing groups.
It is hoped to speak to students at theological colleges about the joys of bell ringing, and a booklet will shortly be published for every vicar in the country, entitled, 'The Bells in Your Care.'
It is recognized by Mr. Baldwin that the church life and experience may no longer be as high a priority.
The greater problem of lack of ringers is also being attacked by Mr. Baldwin.
It is said by one survey that of the 100,000 trained bellringers in England today, only 40,000 of them are still ringing.
Also, the bells are not always rung by ringers where they are needed -- like in small, rural parishes and inner-city churches.
But the program of the council to attract and train ringers is only partly successful, according to Mr. Baldwin.
Right now, one new ringer out of 10 is kept by us if we're lucky after five years, he adds.
One bright sign is that the once male-dominated field has been entered by a growing number of women; more than a third of the ringers today are women.
They are not accepted by everyone, however.

The oldest bell-ringing group in the country, the Ancient Society of College Youths, which was founded in 1637, has remained male-only, a fact that is particularly galling to women since they are excluded from being the source of ringers for Britain's most prestigious churches, including St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

This being Britain, no equal-opportunity suit has been filed by a woman, but the extent of the problem surfaced this summer in a series of letters to `` The Ringing World, `` a weekly newspaper for ringers.

It was remarked by one writer, signing his letter as `` Red-blooded, balanced male, `` that the `` frequency of women fainting in peals `` was notable, and he suggested that they `` settle back into their traditional role of making tea at meetings.``

It was observed by one woman ringer from Solihull in the torrent of replies that followed that the average male ringer was quite badly dressed, decorated with acne and a large beer-belly, frequently unwashed, and left much to be desired, being unbearably flatulent in peals.
It was written by another woman from Sheffield that in her 60 years of ringing, she had never known a lady to faint in the belfry.
One or two men have been seen to die, may they be blessed.
A handful of genes which, if damaged, unleash the chaotic growth of cells that characterizes cancer are being uncovered by medical scientists.
A new and startling picture of how cancer develops is being painted by the discovery of these genes in recent months, scientists say.
An array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention is expected to be produced by an emerging understanding of the genes.
Tests are already being developed by scientists based on the newly identified genes that can, for the first time, predict whether an otherwise healthy individual is likely to get cancer.
A super-exciting set of discoveries has been found by Bert Vogelstein, a Johns Hopkins University researcher, who says he has just discovered a gene pivotal to the triggering of colon cancer.
Only a decade ago, a black box was what cancer was considered to be, about which we knew nothing at the molecular level.
Today, it is known that the accumulation of several of these altered genes can be initiated into a cancer and, then, propelled into a deadly state by them.
The new class of genes is called tumor-suppressors, or simply anti-cancer genes, by scientists.
When functioning normally, proteins that hold a cell's growth in check are made by them.

But if the genes are damaged -- perhaps by radiation, a chemical, or through a chance accident in cell division -- their growth-suppressing proteins are no longer functional, and cells that are normally controlled turn malignant.
For a cell to become malignant, the presence of oncogenes is necessary, but researchers have found them in both normal and cancerous cells, suggesting that cancer is not caused by oncogenes alone.

It has been believed by researchers in recent months that the two types of cancer genes work in concert: proliferating cells may be turned malignant by an oncogene only after the tumor-suppressor gene has been damaged.
Two copies of tumor-suppressor genes, like all genes, are inherited from each parent in turn.
Either copy can be made to have the proteins needed for controlling cell growth, so for cancer to arise, both copies must be impaired.

A person with one defective copy of a suppressor gene at birth, or whose one copy is damaged early in life, is especially prone to cancer because the other copy need only be lost for cancer to develop in them.
Such cancer-susceptible individuals will be spotted by emerging genetic tests, which some scientists believe will usher in a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis.
The new findings have included Bill and Bonnie Quinlan among the first beneficiaries.

It was known to Mr. Quinlan, 30 years old, that he was carrying a damaged gene, having had an eye lost to the rare tumor at only two months old -- a fate that his mother had also suffered when she was a baby.
Because the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene was isolated, it was possible as of last January to determine the threat that faced the Quinlan baby.

It was shown by a test using new `` genetic probes `` that little Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene and, therefore, faced no more risk than other children of developing the rare cancer.
This was the first test that could reliably predict whether an individual was expected to develop cancer.

Equally important, the initial discovery of the gene that controls retinal cell growth was made by a Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja, opening a field of cancer study, which in recent months has exploded.

It is said by Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute, that some fundamental insights about the most basic workings of cancer were made possible by studying a tragic but uncommon tumor.
It may not be obvious to the public which is concerned about advances in treatment, but I am convinced that results will begin to show soon in this basic research.
To date, two of these cancer-suppressors have been identified by scientists.
The retinoblastoma discovery was made by Dr. Dryja in 1986.
Then last spring, a gene called p53, if impaired, was reported by researchers to turn healthy colon cells cancerous.
Evidence that the same damaged p53 gene is present in tissue from lung and breast cancers was soon after that report uncovered by two other research teams.
Almost 200,000 Americans are collectively killed by colon, lung, and breast cancers, which are the most common and lethal forms of the disease, each year.
About seven candidates are being considered by them.

The inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes, alone or in combination, appears to be crucial for the development of such scourges as cancer of the brain, skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix, according to researchers.

It is evidenced that if defective versions of these genes are inherited by people, they are especially prone to cancer, perhaps explaining, finally, why certain families seem to be haunted by some cancers.
It was theorized that in eye cancer, a damaged copy of a gene is inherited by an infant from one parent, and a normal copy from the other.
He suggested that the tumor developed when the second, normal copy was also damaged.
Dr. Knudson 's `` two-hit `` theory could not be proven by any means.
Back then, specific genes could not be ferreted out by scientists, but the 23 pairs of chromosomes in the cells containing the genes could be seen under a microscope.
Gross chromosome damage was occasionally visible.
It was found by Dr. Knudson that a damaged copy of chromosome No. 13 had been inherited by some children with eye cancer from a parent who had had the disease.
Under a microscope it could actually be seen that a bit of chromosome 13 was missing.
It was assumed that the missing piece contained a gene or genes whose loss played a critical role in triggering the cancer.
But it was not known by him which gene or genes had disappeared.
Then, the answer was found by a scientific team led by the molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, who was then at the University of Utah.
A battery of the newly developed `` gene probes, `` snippets of genetic material that can track a gene's presence in a cell, was used by the team.
Defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the exact area as in the first copy of the chromosome were found by analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors.
Dr. Knudson, now at Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia, is said to have found it extraordinarily satisfying.
It was convincing to me that what was true of retinoblastoma would be true for all cancers.
An audacious claim was made.

But in Baltimore, it was believed by Dr. Vogelstein, a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, that Dr. Knudson was right, and the Cavenee experiment was set out to be repeated in cells from other cancers by him.
Dual chromosome losses for a rare childhood cancer of the kidney called Wilm's tumor were reported by his research team, one of two in 1984.
Colon cancer, the second biggest cancer killer in the U.S. after lung cancer, next received the attention of Dr. Vogelstein.
It was believed that colon cancer might also arise from multiple `` hits `` on cancer suppressor genes, because it often seems to develop in stages.

The development of polyps in the bowel often precedes it, which in some cases are increasingly becoming malignant in identifiable stages -- progressing from less severe to deadly -- as though a cascade of genetic damage might be occurring.
Months of tedious and often frustrating probing of the chromosomes, searching for signs of genetic damage, were begun by Dr. Vogelstein and a doctoral student, Eric Fearon.
A confusing variety of genetic deletions was begun to be uncovered by them, some existing only in benign polyps, others in malignant cells, and many in both polyps and malignant cells.
If benign polyps were to develop, it would be due to both copies of a certain gene being knocked out.
It was clear that colon cancer developed only when more than one gene was damaged.
Other molecular biologists were galvanized by their report.
It was the confirming evidence that all of us needed to know that gene losses are critical in the development of a common tumor, Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City says.
But the identity of the gene that, if damaged, flipped a colon cell into full-blown malignancy had yet to be nailed by Dr. Vogelstein.
Chromosome 17 was the focus of their attention.
A gene would probably be constituted by such a piece of DNA.
When it was found last winter, Dr. Vogelstein was dubious that the search had been completed.
The deletion in exactly the same spot as p53 was found by Dr. Vogelstein.
It was said by Mr. Levine that the p53 gene caused cancer by promoting growth, whereas a gene that suppressed growth was being looked for by the Johns Hopkins scientists.

Despite that, when the gene found in human cancer cells by the Johns Hopkins scientists was compared with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, the two were found to be identical; it was discovered that in Mr. Levine's cancer studies, a damaged form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene -- had been unknowingly observed by him.
An obscure gene is suddenly put right in the cockpit of cancer formation by the discovery, says Robert Weinberg, a leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass.
It is now being evidenced that the p53 suppressor gene is also involved in other cancers.
In 23 of 38 breast tumors, one copy of chromosome 17 was found to be mutated at the spot where gene p53 lies by researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland.
It is said by the scientists that since multiple members of certain families are often struck by breast cancer, women may be predisposed to the cancer when the gene is inherited in a damaged form.
Lung cancer has just been associated with the p53 gene.
There also are reports from several labs , as yet unpublished , of p53 genes missing in tissue taken from kidney , brain and skin cancers .
At the same time, other tumor-suppressor genes are being pinpointed by the Johns Hopkins team and others.
One on chromosome 18, also involved in colon cancer, is hoped to be isolated soon by Dr. Vogelstein.
Another gene involved with some types of colon cancer, thought to be on chromosome 5, is close to being found by Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a researcher in Great Britain.
It is believed by Dr. Minna that people, especially those who inherit a defective gene somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3, are prone to lung cancer.
It was recently reported by him and others that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may also be involved in some lung cancers, as well as several other more common cancers, too.

The anticipated cascade of discoveries is being turned into predictive tests and, maybe, new therapies by two major pharmaceutical companies, the Squibb unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., which are collaborating with gene hunters already.
It is said by some researchers that new cancer drugs to slow or reverse tumor growth may be based on suppressor proteins normally produced by the genes.
The growth-controlling proteins made by healthy versions of the damaged genes would be administered to patients.
It may even be possible for defective genes to be replaced with healthy versions, though no one has come close to doing that so far.
Why can our children not be taught to read, write, and reckon?

And the reason we are not wanted to do so is because some cherished metaphysical beliefs about human nature in general and the human nature of young people in particular would have to be relinquished, as well as some cherished vested interests violated, for effective education to be achieved.
Our educational establishment, media, politicians, and even parents are so dominated by these beliefs that it seems almost blasphemous to challenge them.
An example is provided here.
If a sample of American parents were asked, `` Do you wish for the elementary schools to encourage creativity in your children? `` the near-unanimous answer would be, `` Yes, of course. ``
But what is meant, specifically, by `` creativity ``?
Nothing can be said by anyone.
A generation of young people is characterized by ignorance and intellectual incompetence, which is only matched by their good opinion of themselves.

A romantic rebellion against disciplined instruction, which was (and is) considered `` authoritarian, `` a repression and frustration of the latent talents and the wonderful, if as yet undefined, potentialities inherent in the souls of all our children, was (and is) an integral part of the whole notion of `` creativity `` in education.
This romantic extravagance is found so attractive by parents, which is not surprising.
Fortunately, a decent education as traditionally understood is wanted by these same parents for their children, and they have enough common sense to know the demands that it entails.
The degree to which we -- all of us -- allow this common sense to prevail over the illusions that we also share will determine the future of American education.
Common sense will be fought against by the education establishment every inch of the way.
One simple reason ought not to be underestimated , although the complexity of the reasons is significant.
Disciplined instruction is far less interesting and agreeable to teachers than is progressive education, as it was once called.
It is nice for teachers to think they are engaged in `` personality development `` and even nicer for those irksome tests with often disappointing results to be minimized by them.
A superior self-definition as a `` profession `` is also provided to teachers, since they will have passed courses in educational psychology and educational philosophy.
But it is unfair for teachers to be dumped on, as distinct from the educational establishment.
It is known by me that many schoolteachers are, on the whole, seriously committed to conscientious teaching.
It may not be the case that they are counted among the `` best and brightest `` of their generation -- very few such people exist, by definition.
But their jobs can be done well without them needing to.
Yes, one or two truly inspiring teachers can be remembered by us all from our school days.
In this sense, one's family doctor can be compared to a teacher.
If he were brilliant, a family doctor would probably not be his position in the first place.
If he is competent and conscientious, he is served well by us.
Our educational crisis is not significantly affected by our teachers.
Whether they are or are not underpaid is a problem of equity that is not considered an educational issue.
It is silly libel on our teachers to think that our children would be educated better by them if only they received a few thousand dollars more per year.
It is also the kind of libel that is found useful by politicians, since it helps them strike a friendly posture on behalf of an important constituency.
But there is not one shred of evidence that, when other things are equal, educational differentials result from salary differentials.
If such evidence were to exist, you could be sure it would have been brought to your attention.
There are many successful schools scattered throughout this nation, some of which are found in the poorest of ghettos, and the same message is sent to us by them all.
Conversely, the majority of unsuccessful schools are known by us, and it is known beforehand which efforts at educational reform are doomed.
All we need to know is really known by us, if only this knowledge could be assimilated into our thinking by us.
The conventional pap is inevitably echoed by them, since it is the least controversial option that is open to them.
It was announced by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas at the recent governors' conference on education that `` this country needs a comprehensive child-development policy for children under five. ``
A more pressing need would seem to be a comprehensive development policy for governors over 30.
The extension of the educational system down to the pre-kindergarten years is being advocated by Gov. Clinton, in effect.
Whether desirable or not, this child-care program is not considered an educational program.
It is known that very early exposure to schooling improves performance in the first grade, but afterward the difference is quickly washed away.
Schools are too likely to be blamed by parents for the educational limitations of their children.
It should be ensured by them that their kids do not play truant; they should make certain that enough time is spent by the children on homework; the report card should be scrutinized by them.
If a school is found to be unsatisfactory by parents, the option of switching to another should be available to them.
An even worse idea is community involvement.
Here, the decisive experience is that of New York City.
A 20-year-old commitment to this system of school governance is being disengaged from by New York, which is in the process of trying to do so, even as Chicago and other cities move to institute it.
In most states, things will probably be made worse, not better, by increasing expenditures on education in our current circumstances.
The reason is simple: the influence of money is minimal in the classroom, where education takes place.
The already top-heavy administrative structure is being flowed into by the new money, which busies itself piling more and more paper work on the teachers.

It is a fact that neither mystery nor paradox exists in the decline of educational performance as educational expenditures (in real terms) have sharply increased over the past quarter-of-a-century -- more is spent per pupil than in any other country -- and educational performance has been affected.
The educational ladder should be moved up by students as their academic potential allows.
No student should be graduated from elementary school without having mastered the 3 R 's at the level that prevailed 20 years ago, unless permitted.

It is less to permit the gifted youngsters to flourish ( though that is clearly desirable ) than to ensure that the necessary grounding for further study or for entering the modern world of work is obtained by the less gifted, which is the main purpose of `` tracking ``
The notion that tracking is somehow `` undemocratic `` is considered absurd.
Young men and women are encouraged by education to realize their full academic potential, which is the purpose.
It is not believed by anyone in their right mind that we all have an equal academic potential.
It is generally desired that older textbooks be used -- many of them, alas, out of print -- instead of newer ones.
The latter is considered modish, trendy, often found downright silly, and at best deemed insubstantial.

One of the reasons American students are affected so poorly in math tests, as compared with British, French, German, or Japanese students, is due to the influence of the `` New Math `` on American textbooks and teaching methods.

The appreciation of just how bizarre this situation is -- with students unable to add or subtract being `` taught `` the conceptual basis of mathematical theory -- should be read in the article by Caleb Nelson ( a recent math major at Harvard ), in the November issue of the American Spectator.
Most important of all, the faculty, the curriculum, and all matters of student discipline should be under the large measure of authority of principals in schools.
It is told by study after study -- the most recent from the Brookings Institution -- that the best schools are those that are free of outside interference and are governed by a powerful head.
An unambiguous accountability is inherent in that authority, of course.
Students with higher morale and superior academic performance are produced by schools that are structured in this way.
This is a fact -- though, in view of all the feathers that are ruffled by it, it is not surprising that so little is heard about this fact.

Was the man thought to be drunk or crazy or both?

The guy was thought to be off his rocker by Haney, who looked away from those eyes.
Eyes that were clear, but also bright with a strange intensity, had a sort of cold fire burning behind them.
Why had it not been noticed by him before?
The street was crossed by the stranger, his head seemingly sunk in thought, against the light just as a huge moving van roared through the intersection.
As a matter of fact, the guy would not have been cared about at all if he had been hit.
By then, Haney was being thanked profusely by the stranger, who had one arm around his shoulders as if Haney were an old friend.
So both of them were cursed at by the driver as if they had plotted together to ruin his safe-driving record.

It hadn't been given much thought by Haney at the time.

Phil was usually seen alone, keeping to himself, sitting in a corner and passing the time by nursing his favorite grudges.
But it was decided by him that he would n't mind the company in return for free drinks, even though good money was made by him at his job.
That was how Phil was regarded.
The offer was not really taken seriously by him, but he began to feel uneasy.

It seems there is no one I can think of, Pete.
I don't think I am being taken seriously by you, Phil.
I might have been hit by that truck if it wasn't for you.

Five minutes later, before Haney's break could be made, the stranger stood up and nodded farewell.
The small but wiry man was watched by Haney as he slipped out the door quickly and silently, and Haney felt relieved that it seemed nobody else noticed his departure.
It was decided by Phil to stay a little longer, and as time passed, it seemed as if the strange little man had never been there, but for the other glass on the table.
Some time before midnight, his apartment was returned to by him, and he hit the sack, with the whole incident being put out of his mind before he fell asleep.
Haney was reminded by the hangover the next day, Sunday, of where he had been the night before.
The surly landlord was passed by him later in the day as he went for more aspirin; he was still alive and scowling as usual, as if the tenants were a burden in his life.
By Wednesday it was still indicated that the landlord was alive.
A police car was parked in front of the apartment building, which he was startled to see when coming home from work.
Inside the lobby, people were standing around and being talked to excitedly.
A foreboding premonition crawled up his spine as one of his fellow tenants was asked what had happened.
The death of the landlord had occurred.
It appeared that he had been alone.
The fall was not witnessed by anybody -- just the sickening impact when the body was smashed on the pavement just outside the basement delivery entrance.
After a while he began to feel better about it , especially when no questions were asked by anyone .
But after all, why should they be made to?
Still later, he was finally convinced that it was a coincidence -- just an accident.
It was really not related to the stranger, of course.
At least that lousy landlord was gotten rid of by Haney, making him happy as he went to bed.
Really, he said to himself, a man is not killed just as a favor!
So it was thought by you that I didn't mean what I said.
The stranger's feelings appeared to have been hurt by Phil Haney, his eyes looking large and sad.
It was like a recurrent, annoying dream, but now the overtones of a nightmare were beginning to be taken on by the dream.
However, it was known by Haney not to be a dream.
The usual corner at the little table had been sat in by him, as far as possible from any talkative, friendly lushes.
The weekly ritual of washing down his pet grievance with bourbon slightly moistened with water was being enjoyed by him.
Toward the end of his fourth hairy highball, while the table-top was being moodily marked with wet rings by the bottom of the glass, he became aware that he was not alone.
The stranger was seen sitting across the table by him, as he looked up with bloodshot eyes, smiling a secret smile, as if they were fellow conspirators.
Haney felt like he was being made to shrink out of sight, but he was already trapped in the corner by the wiry, dark little man.
Was a creep going to be saddled with him from now on as a bar-buddy?
Phil was asked by the man in a low voice, almost whispering, if he was happy with the way the landlord had been taken off his back.
The mistake of answering in an offhand way was made by him, and his skepticism must have been shown in his face or voice, which he instantly realized.
A slight frown appeared on Pete's face, followed by him becoming sad and moody.
The guy was obviously upset by Haney's lack of appreciation, sulking over his drink.
The uncomfortable silence was broken as Haney began to talk.
When his throat was moistened as he paused, the stranger broke in.
But why are her bills being paid?
If she is seen running around with other men, and if she is truly hated by you as you claim, why not just file for divorce against her ``?
Haney was scowled at.
Community property is dealt with -- you know.
My business would have to be sold out to pay off her share.
It is seen by me now.
It must be understood that I haven't been in this state too long.
I was brought out here to be retired.
I should have been told about her by you before `` .
A twinge of annoyance was felt by Haney when the now familiar line was heard by him again.
A professional killer was retired
If he was just a nut, harm was not done to anyone.
He said gently that no offense was intended.
The cops were not suspected of anything, and I thought it was a coincidence.
After all, you, Pete, were not known to me.
An accident could have been caused.
It looked like an accident had occurred.
It will be proven by me, Phil.
One more favor for you, I think, can be managed by me.

It is known that Republicans are favored more by voters in races for president than in those for Congress.

In every presidential election over the past half century, except for the Goldwater presidential candidacy, a greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president has been captured by the GOP than has been captured by congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress.
Prior to 1932, the opposite was nearly the case with the pattern.
The results of recent decades are accounted for by what?
At least a partial explanation for the split personality displayed by Americans in the voting booth may be provided by a simple economic theory.
Three assumptions are relied upon by the theory:

One of two brands can be `` bought `` by voters when they select their political agents -- a Republican brand that is believed in by those who advocate for the minimalist state and the virtues of private markets over the vices of public action, and a Democratic brand that is believed in by those who support big government and public intervention to remedy the excesses resulting from the pursuit of private interest.

Two basic responsibilities are handled by Congressional representatives while voting in office -- national issues are dealt with (programmatic actions such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on the population at large) and local issues are attended to (constituency service and pork barrel).
Local benefit-seeking is less engaged in by Republican congressional representatives, because of their belief in a minimalist state, than by Democratic members of Congress.

If a Republican is put into office, not only will less local benefits be acquired by them, but their selected legislator will be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from `` bringing home the bacon `` to their respective constituencies.
When it comes to national policy making, each legislator is only one out of 535, after all.

Second, it is explained why Congress is held in disdain by voters but their own congressional representatives are generally loved: The specific benefits that any individual legislator wins for their constituents are appreciated, but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing the same for his own constituency.
Third, it is suggested by the theory that legislators who pay too much attention to national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking experience lower security in office.
For example, once the most vulnerable of incumbents, first-term members of the House have virtually become immune to being defeated.
The defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982 was the one exception to this recent trend.

Fourth, it is indicated by the theory why viable candidates may have a difficult time being attracted by the Republican Party for congressional office.
The congressional salary may be less of a discouragement to potential candidates than the prospect of defeat by a Democratic opponent.

Fifth, at least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South may be provided by the theory.

To the extent that a disproportionate share of power in Congress has been held by Democratic legislators from the South since 1932 and such clout has been able to be translated into relatively more local benefits for their respective constituencies by them, an especially strong incentive to keep such Democrats in office has been had by voters in the South.
Finally, it is suggested by the theory why Senate races have generally been better for Republicans than campaigns for the House.
Does this theory have any empirical support?
The key assumption that Democratic legislators are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Republican colleagues is corroborated by three pieces of evidence.
It is found by economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo that roughly 10% more of the allocated personal staff budgets are turned back by GOP senators than by Democrats.

To the extent that local benefit-seeking is involved in the primary duty of personal staff, this indicates that congressional Republicans are led by their political philosophy to pay less attention to narrow constituent concerns.
This is indeed what is indicated by the data, particularly in the case of the House.
The Democratic House attendance rate was exceeded by the Republicans.

An additional piece of evidence from the Senate suggests that, when holding other factors constant, such as incumbency advantages and regional differences, the discrepancy in popular votes between Republican presidential and senatorial candidates in states conducting a Senate election is found to be a positive function of the onerousness of the federal government's tax burden per state -LRB- with a progressive tax rate impacting higher-income states more severely -RRB-.
GOP candidates for president are looked on more kindly by voters than are Republican candidates for the Senate when the prisoner's dilemma is more severe.
Moreover, the same peculiar pattern of ticket splitting appears to be taken at the state government level as it is at the federal level.

Harrison Jr., from its inception as a small manufacturing company to its status as a full-fledged defense contractor, with the task of producing vital equipment for the Army and Navy entrusted to it.

A last-minute read interloping attendee at a French journalism convention, I had been taking part in festivities that were entirely composed of eating, drinking, smoking, sleeping, and more drinking.

During the past 25 years, the number of balloonists who have passed a Federal Aviation Authority lighter-than-air test has been swelled from a couple hundred to several thousand, with some estimates running as high as 10,000.

I was prompted to sign up by the naggings of a culture imperative.
It will also be told to you that even if you hate heights, you can still be ballooned.
At least not when you are being ascended.
What they wo n't tell you is that you should not be taken aloft in anything you do n't want to get wet.
The traditional champagne drenching is not what I am referring to during the back-on-terra-firma toast.
Landing in a canal is what I'm talking about.
To wit, the beginning of my maiden voyage and novitiates referred to as virgins was at dawn on a dew-sodden fairway, and their end occurred at noon in a soggy field.
Balloon flights almost always occur at dawn or dusk, when the lightest winds are experienced.

In between, lots of coffee drinking and watching the balloons being inflated took place, along with much standing around deciding who would be flown by whom in the balloons and in what order the baskets, holding no more than four passengers, would be allocated.

It's hard not to feel that God's in his heaven with this kind of bird's-eye view of the world, even if it was all pointed out as `` belle `` by your pilote in a silly plaid beret.
The other rule of thumb about ballooning is that steering is not possible.

What's he doing?' was hissed by my companion, who was the only other English-speaking member of the convention and whose knuckles were white.

Plan to reduce emissions is drafted by U.N. group

A document outlining ambitious greenhouse-gas reductions over the next 40 years, with industrialized nations shouldering most of the burden in the near term, was released Friday, renewing focus on the U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations.
The remaining obstacles were highlighted and a path forward was illuminated by the text, which could provide the basis for a final political deal to regulate greenhouse gases.
But what was seen as an important advance in a negotiation running out of time was the arrival of more than 100 world leaders in Copenhagen next week.

A U.N. ad-hoc working groupforged the text, which remains silent on the issue of how much money poor countries would receive from rich ones to cope with global warming over both the short and long term.

A range of options is provided for the key questions, including how developed and major emerging economies would have their carbon output cut, and what the upper limit of global temperature rise would be that policymakers would be willing to tolerate.
A lot of flexibility is given to the process, said John Coequyt, senior Washington representative for the Sierra Club.

The six-page document was drafted by Michael Zammit Cutajar, who reduced a 180-page negotiation text to focus on what was described by Yvo de Boer, the U.N.'s top climate official, as 'the big picture.'

The outlines for a possible deal are shown, in which industrial nations would collectively have their emissions cut by 2020 by 25 to 45 percent compared with 1990 levels, and major developing countries would have theirs reduced during the same period by 15 to 30 percent.
Emissions would be cut between 50 and 95 percent by the countries together by 2050.

The talks were given a boost by the European Union as well on Friday with a pledge to provide $3.6 billion a year over the next three years to help poorer countries adapt to the impact of climate change, ranging from coping with flood and drought to avoiding deforestation.
Still, the same sort of verbal fireworks that have dominated the talks for the past week were featured on Friday.

A deal is not going to be done by the United States without the major developing countries stepping up and taking action, according to Stern, who also complained that the text was insufficient in ensuring the cuts could be verified by outside observers.

The comments were made by Stern an hour after it was said by Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei that America's top climate negotiator was either lacking 'common sense' or being 'extremely irresponsible' for having stated earlier in the week that financial assistance to China in coping with global warming would not be provided by the United States.

As much as the current battle is about saving individual economies and the planet, the respective obligations of China and the United States are being feuded over, while the poorer nations insist that the world's two dozen most influential countries are ignoring the scientific imperative for bolder action to be taken.

It was said by Ricardo Ulate, a Costa Rican delegate, that it's not surprising the major powers are fighting over who should bear the costs for curbing greenhouse gases, even as vulnerable countries have become more aggressive in seeking to hold the big emitters accountable for their actions.
It was clearly a game where a new economic hegemony is being developed, said Ulate, who also serves as the regional Mexico and Central America climate change adviser for Conservation International.

A legally binding treaty in Copenhagen was indicated to be continued to be pushed for by some of the countries most vulnerable to the impact of climate change, although most of the major participants say the talks will produce a political deal at best.
A 24-page draft treaty proposal was produced by the Alliance of Small Island States, which has 43 members, early Friday morning.

Artur Runge-Metzger, who leads international climate negotiations on behalf of the European Commission, stated that political pressure has been `` put on the entire political process `` by the push from small island nations, in part because they are now united and demanding action from emerging economies such as China and India.

New urgency was taken on by the talks as the fact that most of the outstanding issues must be resolved by the delegates before the arrival of the heads of government to strike a deal was focused upon.

Closed-door meetings and news conferences were staked out by high-level officials such as Indian environment minister Jairam Ramesh and the Chinese vice minister, who stepped off planes and raced through the Bella Center's halls, to claim arbitration over the next week.

A challenge is posed by the vast sprawl of the gathering -- where 13,000 people move in and out of the convention center each day, nightly shows are put on by guitar-playing activists mocking the countries they believe are selling out, and draft proposals are passed by hand on paper instead of via e-mail.
Nearly all of the key ministers are now here, and as early as Wednesday, Copenhagen will have 60 heads of government, with the intensity only building.
Carlos Manuel Rodriguez, vice president for global policy at Conservation International, said they were getting into the big leagues.
The arrival of the heavyweights is imminent.

On Thursday, an official end is set to come to the widely followed trial of Steven J. Hayes, who was convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire, Conn. family, with the death sentence voted for by the jury being imposed by the judge.

A `` circus atmosphere `` was created by the intense reporting on the trial - including the extensive use of Twitter by mainstream reporters - which led to such widespread, instant saturation with inflammatory details that the jury was improperly swayed by public passions.
The question of whether new technology requires new courtroom rules could be forced on appeals judges by the claim.

The debate arising in the related case is partly due to the fact that the team of the Real Madrid organization, which presumes nobility and honor in its hymn and has fined its players for similar acts, has been carried out, as well as the dramatization seemingly orchestrated by Mourinho, who has added another incident to his extensive history as a histrionic and provoking technician.
The physical integrity of the opposite players, which is one of the advantages that include the sport spirit, was not put into danger by these actions, meaning there was no violent game.

Another question is what type of advantage was obtained by the violators in the actions they deliberately carried out.

The sporting spirit, which is part of the strategic decisions, is really contravened by those actions that favor taking advantages allowed by the rules.

Regarding this assumption, the players did not act in order to avoid the application of the sanction, but rather chose when to obey it, which would have been a clear case of legal fraud if not for their actions.
Although the border between wittiness and law fraud is diffuse, in this occasion it was believed to be a clear case of wittiness.
The controversy seems to stem from two factors: due to two auto expulsions and the manner in which the directive's transmission was conducted to result in them.

The possibility of new types of life on Earth, or elsewhere, is raised by an arsenic-tolerant microbe.
A strange bacteria that can use arsenic as one of its nutrients has been discovered, widening the scope for finding new forms of life on Earth and possibly beyond.
While the unusual bacteria were discovered by researchers here on Earth, it is said that they indicate life has possibilities beyond the major elements that have been considered essential.
Dual capability is possessed by this organism.
Either phosphorus or arsenic can be used for its growth.

It was commented by Paul C. W. Davies of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report appearing in Thursday's online edition of the journal Science, that it is very peculiar, though it falls short of being some form of truly 'alien' life.
Life has long been considered to depend on six major elements - carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
It was found by the researchers that the bacteria, discovered in Mono Lake, Calif., is able to continue growing by substituting arsenic for phosphorus.
It was Ariel D. Anbar of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report, who said, 'It makes you wonder what else is possible.'
The find is considered important by researchers in the search for life beyond Earth because they need to be able to recognize what life looks like, as Anbar said.
A microbe found on Earth is the focus of the study.

However, a news conference to discuss it, which did not disclose details of the find, was the subject of widespread speculation on the Internet that the discovery of extraterrestrial life would be disclosed in the report.
It was not done.

It was commented by Charles Cockell, professor at Planetary and Space Sciences Research Institute, Open University, in Milton Keynes, United Kingdom, that the discovery `` shows that in other planetary environments, organisms might be able to use other elements to drive biochemistry, and that the 'standard' set of elements we believe are absolutely necessary for life might not be so fixed.'
The research team did not include Cockell.
The substitution of one element for another in fundamental biochemistry and biochemical structure is shown by this novel work, added Cockell.
The study was led by Felisa Wolfe-Simon of NASA's Astrobiology Institute, who targeted Mono Lake due to its high arsenic levels.
It was speculated by her that a microbe exposed to both arsenic and phosphorus might be able to substitute one for the other, as they are chemically similar.
Its chemical behavior being so similar to that of phosphorus makes arsenic toxic.
These elements are hard to be told apart by organisms as a result.
But phosphorus works much better than arsenic, which, when it gets in there, gums up the works of our biochemical machinery, explained Anbar.
The bacteria known as GFAJ-1 was collected by the researchers and exposed to increasing concentrations of arsenic, to which it was able to adapt and grow.

The possibility is raised that a life form using arsenic could occur naturally, either elsewhere on Earth or on another planet or moon where arsenic is more common, by showing that the microbe can live with arsenic instead of growing better on phosphorus.

The idea that arsenic could be substituted for phosphorus, said Jamie S. Foster, an assistant professor of microbiology at the University of Florida, isn't new, but there has never been an example shown to work, according to him.
Arsenic, she said, has been speculated by researchers to have been used by early life forms, as it was more common in the early times on Earth.
It does suggest that there could be other ways to form life, not just how life formed on early Earth, Foster said, who was not part of Wolfe-Simon's research team.
NASA, the Department of Energy, and the National Institutes of Health supported the research.
Support for democracy in Latin America continues to be edged up, as does backing for private enterprise.
Unemployment has been surpassed by crime as a greater worry.
Much of the region sees Brazil as more influential than the United States.
Some of the findings of the latest Latinobarómetro poll, taken in 18 countries, were exclusively published by The Economist.
Because the poll has been taken regularly since 1995, changes in attitude across the region have been tracked by it.
The results of this year's poll, taken in September and early October, highlight two related things.
Democracy has been noticed to receive increased support in several countries on the Pacific rim of South America (see table 1).
For example in Peru, where economic growth averaging 6% a year since 2002 has been experienced, democracy has been supported increasingly from a low of 40% in 2005 to 61% this year.
But only around half of the region's two most populous countries, Mexico and Brazil, have respondents who are convinced democrats, which drags down the regional average (see chart 2).

Some 44 % of respondents across the region were pronounced satisfied by how their country's democracy works in practice, a figure the same as last year but marking a big increase from the 25 % in 2001 (chart 3).

Some 34 % of the people expressed confidence in their country's Congress, and 45 % in their government, with the figures being the same as those of the previous year in both instances, but showing a sharp increase from the respective percentages of 17 % and 24 % in 2003.
Support for democracy was undermined by economic woes in Latin America a decade ago.
It is probably because many Latin American countries only suffered a brief recession and have enjoyed a strong recovery that the world financial crisis has held up.
The poor have been helped to be shielded by a stronger social safety net, in addition.

It was reported by the United Nations' Economic Commission for Latin America this week that the proportion of Latin Americans living in poverty rose only marginally in 2009 and has fallen again this year, to 32%.
A widely shared sense of progress is reflected by Brazil's strong economic performance and the popularity of its outgoing president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
Scarcity is more pronounced in Mexico and Central America, where the recession was more severe and violent crime has been exacerbated.

For only the second time since the polls began, crime is cited by more respondents across Latin America as a whole, rather than unemployment, as the most important problem facing their country (see chart 5).
Some 31 % say that either they or a close relative have been victims of crime over the past year, with the figure being down from 38 % the previous year and marking the lowest since 1995.

Rising support for private enterprise and the market economy reflects a more robust economic performance: some 71% of respondents across the region say that development is indispensable with private enterprise, an increase from 56% in 2007 (see chart 6).
Some 58 % agree that their country can only be developed by the market economy system, an increase from 47 % last year.

Interestingly, that view is held by 62% of respondents in Venezuela (and 80% there support private enterprise) even though many private companies are being expropriated by their left-wing president, Hugo Chávez.

Most leadership in the region is exercised by Brazil, according to 19% of respondents (up from 18% last year), with the United States (9%, unchanged from last year) and Venezuela (9%, down from 11% last year) following.

But the United States is considered the most influential country by respondents in Mexico and much of Central America, while that distinction is enjoyed by Venezuela in Ecuador, the Dominican Republic, and Nicaragua.

The day a challenge to President Obama's healthcare law was considered by the Supreme Court behind closed doors, a dinner was hosted by the law firm that will argue the case before the high court, celebrating two of its justices, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, amidst the politically divisive question of whether the court would hear the case.

A suit brought by 26 states, challenging the sweeping healthcare overhaul passed by Congress last year, was one of the cases at issue, a law that has been a rallying cry for conservative activists nationwide.

The suit was agreed to be heard by the justices; indeed, a landmark 5.5-hour argument is expected to be held in March, and the 2012 presidential race is likely to be further roiled by the outcome, which will be in full swing at the time the decision of the court is released.
It is likely that Paul Clement, who served as U.S. solicitor general during the George W. Bush administration, will be the lawyer standing before the court to argue for the law to be thrown out.

The annual dinner of the Federalist Society, a longstanding group dedicated to advocating conservative legal principles, was sponsored by almost two dozen firms, including Clement's law firm, Bancroft PLLC.
The dinner was sponsored by another firm , Jones Day , which represents one of the trade associations , the National Federation of Independent Business , that challenged the law.
Another sponsor, pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc, in which an enormous financial stake is held, is dependent on the outcome of the litigation.
A Washington hotel hosted the dinner hours after the court's conference over the case was held.
Mitch McConnell, the Senate's top Republican and an avowed opponent of the healthcare law, was in attendance, among others.
The dinner featured guests Scalia and Thomas.
It's nothing new: Federalist Society events have been attended by the two justices for years.

If they were, they arguably fell under Canon 4C of the code, which states that fund-raising events of law-related and other organizations may be attended by a judge, although the judge may not speak, be honored, or be featured on the program of such an event.
Nevertheless, ethics-in-government activists were alarmed by the sheer proximity of Scalia and Thomas to two of the law firms in the case, as well as to a company with a massive financial interest.
Any claims of impartiality are undercut by their appearance and assistance in fundraising for this event, and are deemed unacceptable.
Little regard has been shown by Scalia and Thomas for critics who say they too readily mix the business of the court with agenda-driven groups such as the Federalist Society.
And Ginni, the wife of Thomas, is considered a high-profile conservative activist.
It is argued by conservatives that Justice Elena Kagan, not Scalia and Thomas, has an ethical issue.
When the first legal challenges to the law were brought at the trial court level, Kagan was serving as solicitor general in the Obama administration.
Kagan has been pushed by her critics to recuse herself from hearing the case, with them saying that she was too invested in defending the law then to be impartial now.
No indication has been given by Kagan that she will do so.

Nicolas Sarkozy's immigration policy was subject to criticism from various aspects, with a congestion of police, legal and administrative services being subjected to a policy based on numbers and its compatibility with the self-proclaimed status of the country as the protector of French human rights.

More recently, administrative harassment of foreign students has been declared as topical by the minister of the interior (`` Libération `` on 23 May), who stated that France `` does not need foreign talent, bricklayers, and waiters.'
But the economic viewpoint is only rarely used for analysis.
A lot of consensus on this subject is shared between the Left and the Right.

The tone was set on the Right by Jacques Chirac, who declared in 1976 that `` 900,000 unemployed would not become a problem in a country with 2 million of foreign workers, `` and on the Left by Michel Rocard, who explained in 1990 that France `` can not accommodate all the world's misery. ``
The degree of generosity is the only difference
In 2005, the national territory was feared to be invaded by hordes of Polish plumbers, a fear that was felt both on the Left and on the Right.
Immigrants are seen as a burden on the French economy and French society by both sides.
In his program, François Hollande has confined himself to banalities, with the suggestion that our immigration problem could be solved through co-development.
This notion of immigration being considered a burden and a problem may be seen as an electoral asset, but it is recognized as economically very costly.

It is reminded by the economists Ian Goldin and Geoffrey Cameron in a recent book summarising the most recent knowledge of immigration (Exceptional People: How Migration Shaped Our World and Will Define Our Future, mai 2011, Princeton University Press, 352 pp.) that there is wide consensus among specialists on the positive impact of migration flows on economic growth, wages, and employment in countries admitting immigrants.
Anaemic growth is led to by restraining immigration, and employment is harmed.
The notion that immigrants are liable to replace native workers, particularly unskilled ones, leads to fears about the impact on wages, which experience downward pressure.
A shortage of labor in trades is experienced by immigrants, who are considered as replacements.

In the same way as a country with a shortage of anaesthetists would make it difficult for a surgeon to work, the arrival of immigrants, due to the complementarities with locals, has a positive effect on the pay of the locals brought about.
It has been calculated by Giovanni Peri that a rise of 1% in the migratory flow causes an increase of between 0.6 and 0.9% in real long-term pay.

And the fact that the diversity contributed by immigrants is not taken into account, which contributes to the creation of ideas and economic growth, with a large proportion of naturalised immigrants being among American Nobel prize winners, and the founding of companies such as Google, Intel, Paypal, eBay, and Yahoo by immigrants.

It is estimated by the World Labor Organisation that for example in Germany, a net contribution (receipts less expenditure) of an average of 150,000 Euros to public budgets during his lifetime will be made by an immigrant arriving at the age of 30.

A solution for infusion (drip into a vein) is made up from Alimta, which is a powder.
The active substance pemetrexed is contained in it.
For what is Alimta used?
Two types of cancer, including pleural mesothelioma (cancer of the lining of the lungs that is usually caused by exposure to asbestos), are treated with Alimta.

When the cancer is unresectable ( cannot be removed by surgery alone ) and malignant ( has spread, or is likely to spread easily, to other parts of the body ), Alimta, together with cisplatin ( another anticancer medicine ), is used in patients who have not previously received chemotherapy ( medicines for cancer ) for advanced or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer that is not affecting the squamous cells.
Patients who have not been treated before are administered Alimta in combination with cisplatin, and those who have received another type of chemotherapy in the past are given Alimta on its own.
A prescription is required to obtain the medicine.
Alimta should only be given by a doctor who is qualified in the use of anticancer chemotherapy under supervision.
The recommended dose of Alimta, 500 mg per square metre of body surface area, is calculated using the patient's height and weight.
An intravenous infusion lasting 10 minutes is given once every three weeks.
A corticosteroid and folic acid (a type of vitamin) should be taken by patients, and vitamin B12 injections should be received during treatment with Alimta to reduce side effects.

When cisplatin is administered with Alimta, an anti-emetic medicine should be given before or after the cisplatin dose to prevent vomiting, and fluids should also be administered to prevent dehydration.
Patients with abnormal blood counts or certain other side effects should have their treatment delayed or discontinued, or experience a reduction in dose.
Patients with moderate or severe kidney problems should not use Alimta, as it is not recommended.
For more information, the Summary of Product Characteristics (which is also a part of the EPAR) should be seen.
The active substance in Alimta, pemetrexed, which is a cytotoxic medicine belonging to the group of antimetabolites, kills cells that are dividing, such as cancer cells.

In the body, an active form is produced from pemetrexed, which blocks the activity of enzymes involved in the production of nucleotides (the building blocks of DNA and RNA, the genetic material of cells).
How has the study of Alimta been conducted?
For the treatment of malignant pleural mesothelioma, one main study has included the examination of Alimta in 456 patients who had not previously received chemotherapy for their disease.
Alimta in combination with cisplatin was compared for its effects to those of cisplatin alone.

In one study involving 571 patients with locally advanced or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer who had received chemotherapy in the past, the effects of Alimta were compared to those of docetaxel, another anticancer medicine, for their treatment.
A study involving 1,725 patients who had not received chemotherapy for lung cancer in the past also compared Alimta with gemcitabine (another anticancer medicine), both in combination with cisplatin.
What benefit has been shown by Alimta during the studies?
The survival time of patients with malignant pleural mesothelioma was increased by Alimta.
An average survival of 12.1 months was observed in patients receiving Alimta and cisplatin, compared to 9.3 months in those who received cisplatin alone.
In patients who had received chemotherapy in the past, an average survival time of 8.3 months was observed with Alimta, as compared to 7.9 months with docetaxel.
In patients who had not received chemotherapy in the past, an average survival time of 10.3 months was observed in both groups.
However, in both studies, patients whose squamous cells were not affected by cancer had longer survival times when Alimta was received than when the comparator was received.
In contrast, patients with squamous cell cancer that was being affected had shorter survival times if they were treated with Alimta.

It is explained how the studies performed were assessed by the Committee for Medicinal Products for Veterinary Use (CVMP), in order to reach their recommendations on the medicine's use.
The active substance maropitant is contained in Cerenia, which is available as a tablet or as a solution for injection.
The Pfizer logo is marked on one side of each tablet, and the letters MPT along with the quantity of maropitant are marked on the other side.
For what is Cerenia used?
Vomiting is stopped by Cerenia, which means it is an anti-emetic.
Vomiting such as that caused by chemotherapy (medicines used for the treatment of cancer, some of which are known to cause vomiting) is prevented in dogs using it.

Cerenia can also be used in the treatment of vomiting in combination with supportive measures such as other veterinary treatment or a special diet, either as an injection or with tablets following the injection.
For these purposes, up to five days of Cerenia can be administered
A neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor is blocked by Cerenia, which acts in the central nervous system.
How has the study of Cerenia been conducted?
A large number of studies with Cerenia were conducted on either laboratory dogs or animal patients at veterinary practises in several European countries and in the USA.
What benefit has been shown by Cerenia during the studies?

It was shown by the results of the studies that Cerenia was more effective than the placebo: less vomiting was seen in dogs that received the medicine compared to those that received a placebo, both for the treatment and prevention of vomiting.
The injection should be started with the treatment of a vomiting dog, since animals that are vomiting might not be able to retain a tablet ( as they could vomit the intact tablet again ) .
For follow-up treatment, the tablets can be administered to the dog by the animal owner.
Also, vomiting should only be treated in conjunction with other supportive measures or other veterinary therapies while the underlying causes of vomiting are being addressed.
What is the risk that Cerenia is associated with?

Cerenia was generally well tolerated when daily dosages up to 5 times the recommended doses were administered for an extended period of time (up to 3 times the recommended maximum duration of treatment).
What are the precautions that must be taken by the person who gives the medicine or is in contact with the animal?
A particular risk for people is not represented by Cerenia.
